reviews.advice: Put people first and be a bit more humane.  Be professional, don't be vindictive or petty.  Look into native speakerism and take steps to combat it effectively.   Get rid of the 2 tier system.  Ensure your staff are properly trained with adequate support.
reviews.cons:
Unreasonable workload. Difficult to balance work and life, if at all.
Work on the weekends, not much holiday.
Corporate atmosphere - very clear but the flip side is you're just a worker drone.
reviews.pros:
Decent salary and benefits (but could get more with other companies).
Career progression.
Chance to experience working in an international setting.
reviews.summary: Corporate - don't do it if that's not what you like.

reviews.cons: Software delivery is not something the leadership seems to be bothered about. Unrealistic deadlines are constantly made up and the team is put under pressure to meet these deadlines. When the deadlines are missed, there is a shrug of the shoulders and a new made up date is made up and the pattern continues. As a result corners are cut to try and meet the unrealistic timeframes. When presenting evidence, metrics, etc to provide realistic dates you are met with confusion and ignored.
reviews.pros: Great people who just get on with things despite lack of direction.
reviews.summary: Not set up to be a software company

reviews.cons: It's not for everyone; if you like a more traditional workplace with set JDs, rigid hierarchy and predictability in your work i.e. knowing what programs you'll be using a year from now, this isn't the company for you.

reviews.advice: EF is notorious around Boston for it's low salaries, but you get the impression that management already knows that.
reviews.cons: If EF paid higher salaries, I don't think the company would lose as many great employees as it does every year.
reviews.pros: A very young and friendly atmosphere makes EF a great place to come to work everyday.  They also offer great health benefits and lots of vacation.  On top of that, a good work ethic is encouraged, so if or when you do leave the company, you can be sure that you actually have valuable work experience behind you.
reviews.summary: Great place to work for recent grads!

reviews.advice: Engage employees and try to reduce turnover. Engagement and empowerment is more than just company parties and travel perks.
reviews.cons: High turnover in sales. The industry in general has low compensation, but the benefits of travel make up for most of it... however travelling does not pay bills, so it dedpends on what you value
reviews.pros: Great people and a really fun atmosphere. The office is beautiful and the company is always changing which keeps things exciting. Also, the travel perks are pretty spectacular!

As soon as my train pulled in to the station, I was in contact with a representative who helped me move in to my new apartment (which was very nice  - spacious and clean), set me up with basic comforts until I was able to buy them for myself (towels, bedding and food) and basically ensured that my arrival was asI cannot express how much I've enjoyed working for EF Xuzhou over the last year. As soon as my train pulled in to the station, I was in contact with a representative who helped me move in to my new apartment (which was very nice  - spacious and clean), set me up with basic comforts until I was able to buy them for myself (towels, bedding and food) and basically ensured that my arrival was as comfortable as possible. 

Even prior to arriving in Xuzhou, EF ensured that all of my Visa's were handled correctly and processed all of my documentation as smoothly as possible which was a huge reassurance from the outset. 

I was, of course, fairly apprehensive during my first week (as is to be expected when starting a new job in a new country), but can say that the training with which I was provided immediately put me at ease. I was given an introduction to the various age groups I would teach and learned a lot about the approaches to take when teaching them. The trainers are fully aware that the first week or so can be a daunting experience for a new teacher, and try to give a gradual induction so as not to overwhelm them with too much information all at once. 
Training is ongoing, with meetings held each week covering a wide range of different aspects related to teaching. This means that the employees are always developing, being introduced to new material and becoming better teachers. 

During my first few weeks at EF Xuzhou, I was provided with a personal mentor (an experienced member of the teaching faculty) who instructed me in all areas of my new job (from lesson planning to navigating the computer system) and who was able to answer any general questions I may have had.  

The atmosphere in the office is friendly and supportive and the staff; sociable. Annual trips are usually provided by the company and are great opportunities for team bonding as well as a well deserved break for the staff. 

I have worked at EF Xuzhou for just under a year and am more than happy to stay here. I can wholeheartedly recommend EF Xuzhou to anybody with a serious interest in pursuing a career in ESL in an authentic Chinese city which manages to incorporate elements of both modern China and the more traditional way of life.

reviews.advice: The EF program is fantastic and has a good name recognition and branding. I would pay more attention to what each individual franchise is up to, however, because a few schools could easily make a really bad name for themselves, and by extension, the entire brand.
reviews.cons:
-They expect you to get way too much work done in way too short of a time. work-life balance horrible.
-Pay is super sketchy- cash with no pay stub or any other record for you.
-The provided apartments (that you're "strongly encouraged" to accept) are frequently in disrepair or substandard condition. There is a handyman who will repair things, but he has to come by pretty frequently. Oh, and he can drop by your apartment any time unannounced if management decides to so a spot inspection.
-Utilities for the provided apartments are 350-450 yuan a month per person. I have since learned that this amount is more than double what utilities should cost for an entire apartment, yet they're collecting that amount from each person in the 2 or 3 bedroom apartments. That means someone is skimming money off the teachers and keeping it for themselves. This amount is deducted from your base pay of 7000 yuan each month (which is already quite low compared to market) before you get it.
-There is a 2 months notice policy if you wish to leave your contract early, instead of the standard 30 days.
-One of the schools in my area was heavily fined by the government within the past year for charging parents a different amount that was on the invoice.
-Recent managerial changes have resulted in some sort of power play and turf war between managers, and it seems like the battle revolves around who can micro-manage their teachers the most. Not even 6 months ago corporate gave us the New High Fliers program, a fancy new curriculum designed by people from Cartoon Network. It's awesome. However, new management has decided that we have to disregard the provided lesson plans and rewrite every single lesson to conform to an overly strict and honestly impossible scaffolding schedule. It calls for more minutes than are in the class. Instructions are confusing at best and outright conflicting at worst. We have to fit in eight 5-10 minute fun activities per hour of class time, yet we're not allowed to play what has been deemed as "crazy games" but not yet defined as what that includes. On top of all that, we have to write out our lesson plans on specific paper with every step and timing nuance included, and they can be spot inspected at any time.
-On the administration side, the focus is on money. Many of the course coordinators do not actually care about the English level of the student or what is best for them, instead shoving students into whatever available class they think is the closest, just so as to make the sale. It causes a lot of stress and frustration.
-Communication between departments is horrible. You'll be scheduled for events and they'll forget to tell you about it (or actually put it on your schedule) until it starts and you don't show up. Or, they'll suddenly decide to take one of your classes and put a different teacher in charge of it without warning for no discernible reason.
-There is definite favoritism and despotism in the office, where friends of the higher managers get treated much differently.
reviews.pros:
-You get a legal working visa.
-The process to get to China is streamlined and easy, you are assisted in every way. They get you to your provided apartment and help you settle in your first week.
-They reimburse you for your flight there (half after 3 months, half after 6 months).
-The facilities are really nice with modern technology, plenty of resources, and interesting work spaces.
-The age range is 3-adult, so you're able to teach a variety of age levels.
-While the standard time off is extremely limited, you get 10 paid days off that you can use whenever, except for about 5 months of the year.
reviews.summary: Wonderful program, horrible local franchise management.

reviews.advice: Make payments on time; respect your employees and don't try to rip them off.
reviews.cons: Upper management is terrible. All staff in the centre have to 'chase' their pay on a monthly basis - it is awkward having to constantly nag your own boss for him to pay you. Furthermore, these payments often come through short. There are no opportunities for a pay-rise, even if you are involved in a role where the students are paying more (e.g. bilingual classes) - this extra money seems to get lost in the upper management again. Teachers are made to feel expendable and the job is very repetitive and boring.
reviews.pros: Flexible hours and friendly co-workers, combined with not having to travel around the city endlessly as with other EFL jobs in Santiago, make this an attractive option.
